name: Materiales Vallejo
caption: Designing and building a material store’s first website

content.text: Materiales Vallejo is a small building material store in Matamoros, Mexico selling cement, steel rebars, and other building materials to local clients. The business was looking for a website to help the business engage with new clients and to serve as a tool to expedite their hiring process.

Materiales Vallejo’s revenue comes from sales to local material stores, hardware stores, construction firms and individuals. Price negotiations are a very common part of the sales process. As a consequence, phone and in-person interactions are preferred over email and virtual forms of interaction because almost every sale goes through some form of negotiation. Clients engage with the business at least once a week to discuss product availability and pricing and to make new purchase orders.

Materiales Vallejo’s hiring process is very manual and could use some automation. The business purchases newspaper and radio ads to promote an available job. Interested applicants are asked to purchase a job application form at a local office supply store and deliver the application in person or email a scanned copy, making the application process quite slow.

The business is part of a community where businesses are barely starting to engage with users online. The business took interest in building a website because businesses in larger cities were obtaining sales leads through their websites and marketing campaigns. Due to technology and budget limitations, a simple website was built to help Materiales Vallejo engage with local clients and streamline their hiring process.

The core user profile was based on Materiales Vallejo’s client profile. Most clients are construction firm secretaries and small business owners that have purchasing power, are familiar with building material use and terminology, and prefer to engage on the phone with the business to inquire about product availability and negotiate pricing. Core user’s will likely visit the website for quick reference about product and service availability and will call the store to ask about pricing.

Secondary users are users that would visit the website to find out about available jobs and apply online. These users would find out about the available job through a newspaper or radio ad and instead of being sent to purchase an application form, a link would be provided where potential hires will find more details about the job and where they could fill out and submit an application form.

A simple website was designed featuring a landing page, an about page, and dynamic job pages. The landing page provides a fast but complete run-through of the business for core users. The landing page was designed for fast consumption to minimize search time and maximize the probability of turning the visit into an engagement.

The navigation menu is fixed and has a contact button that displays the available form of contact at the time of visit. If the store is open, the button invites users to call the store. If the business is away for lunch or closed, the button invites users to send an email.

media.alt: Dynamic desktop and mobile contact buttons.

content.text: The landing page’s hero section introduces the business and provides links to the products and services sections. The hero’s background is dark to focus the user’s attention on the section’s content. A bright blue color was used for the product button as it contains information users will most likely want to engage the business for.

A carousel was designed to provide a quick way of navigating through the available products. Products were grouped by category for fast product navigation and categories were ordered by popularity. Users can either press a category name or scroll through the swimlane to navigate through the product cards.

Product cards were designed to inform about product availability. Tapping the card displays details about sale unit and available measurements. Product cards don’t display prices because the business values engaging and negotiating with clients.

The contact section displays dynamic content that updates based on the store’s schedule. If the business is open, the section’s description invites users to call the business and the store number is highlighted in blue. If the business is out for lunch or closed, the section’s description informs the user of the store’s status and the email is highlighted in blue.

When there’s an available job the index and about pages display a job banner and a Careers page is displayed listing the available jobs. Each job has a job detail page that displays a brief job description and an application form.

The about page was designed to provide a brief overview of business history, goals, and service standards. The about page displays business details for users interested in learning more about the business and its story. The page provides a brief run-through of the business history, goals, and service standards. The section also contains dynamic content that invites users to take a specific form of action based on the store’s current status.
The website was built with Middleman, Tachyons, and Netlify for fast content editing, dynamic pages, reusable styling, free hosting and continuous deployment.

block.title: Fast Content Editing
block.description: Each page has it's own `.json` data file that contains the page's content, making content easy to locate and fast to update.

block.title: Dynamic Pages
block.description: When a job is available, changing a boolean variable in `jobs.json` activates the job's detail and application pages.

block.title: Reusable Styling
block.description: Tachyons encapsulates CSS properties by function, eliminating specificity issues and enabling easy, predictable UI updates.

block.title: Simple Deployment
block.description: Netlify offers free hosting and integrates with GitHub to provide fast and easy deployment with `git push`.

content.text: Materiales Vallejo’s website was published on December 2016 and will track user data to provide a better insight into user engagement and website use. At the moment, the business is not interested in investing time in ad words campaigns to increase the site’s traffic, so the site will have limited use and value. Nonetheless, I will be monitoring the site’s usage and will get in touch with the business early in 2017 to provide a report of the site’s usage and talk about potential site updates and modifications.

This project was a great learning experience and I had a lot of fun running through the full design and development process. When the project started I had prior experience with website builders, a limited understanding of HTML/CSS, and had never taken care of a website from idea to launch. The mistakes I made and skills I picked up along the way helped gave me enough confidence to tackle challenges I faced on other client projects.
